title: Y is $\sigma (X)$-measurable, show $Y=f(X)$ $f$ a Borel function
body: I am working on the following question for my probability theory class: Let $X, Y$ be random variables on $(\Omega,\mathcal{F}, P)$ such that $Y$ is $\sigma (X)$ -measurable. Show that there is a Borel-measurable function $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ so that $Y=f(X)$ . My plan for this is the following. Let $\mathcal{M}$ be the class of all random variables of the form $f(X)$ where $f$ is a Borel function. Let $\mathcal{A}=\sigma(X).$ I will then show that $\mathcal{M}$ satisfies (i), (ii) and (iii) below: (i) If $f,g\in\mathcal{M}, \ a,b\in\mathbb{R},$ then $af+bg\in\mathcal{M}$ . (ii) If $f_1\leq f_2 \leq f_3 \leq \dots$ is a sequence of functions in $\mathcal{M}$ and $f(\omega)=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} f_n(\omega)<\infty$ for each $\omega\in\Omega$ , then $f\in\mathcal{M}$ . (iii) $1_A \in \mathcal{M}$ for each $A\in \mathcal{A}.$ Once I show that $\mathcal{M}$ satisfies those three conditions by the Monotone Class Theorem I will have that $\mathcal{M}$ contains all $\sigma(\mathcal{A})=\mathcal{A}=\sigma(X)$ -measurable functions. So in particular $Y$ is in $\mathcal{M}$ . So far I believe I have figured out why $\mathcal{M}$ satisfies (i) and (ii). I believe (i) is satisfied because a constant multiple of a measurable function is measurable, and the sum of two measurable functions is measurable. I believe that (ii) is satisfied because the $\limsup$ and $\liminf$ of a sequence of measurable functions is measurable and in this case since the limit exists we have that the $\liminf$ would equal the $\limsup$ would equal the limit. Now what I am having trouble showing is that for each $A\in \sigma(X)=\mathcal{A}$ , $1_A\in\mathcal{M}$ Any help or comments would be appreciated!

title: What are the $\sin$ and $\cos$ of discrete calculus?
body: I'm getting acquainted with Discrete Calculus , and I really like taking functions that arise in traditional calculus and finding what their counterparts in discrete-land are. For example, if we define our difference operator $$\Delta f(n) = f(n + 1) - f(n)$$ (the analogue of the familiar derivative operator $D = \frac{d}{dx}$ ) then we can ask: what is the $e^x$ of this operator? That is, what is the function $g$ such that $\Delta g(n) = g(n)$ ? The answer is $2^x$ , since: $$\Delta 2^x = 2^{x+1} - 2^x = 2(2^x) - 2^x = 2^x$$ Likewise, we can ask what the $g(x) = x^n$ of discrete calculus is -- it turns out to be $$g(x) = \overbrace{x(x - 1)(x - 2) \dots (x - (n - 1))}^{n \text{ factors}}$$ My question is: is there a $\sin$ and $\cos$ of discrete calculus? By which I mean, are there any functions $f$ such that $\Delta^2 f = -f$ ?

Suppose there exists a surjection $f:V\rightarrow V^V$. $V$ is not a singleton, so we can find distinct elements $v_0,v_1$ in $V$. title: Relation between definitions of Lie bracket via adjoint representation and via left-invariant vector fields
body:
I’ve been reading two books that touch on the Lie theory: Representation Theory by Fulton & Harris and Introduction to Manifolds by Loring Tu . They define Lie bracket on tangent space at identity in two different ways, and I want to know how these two approaches can be conciliated.
Short description follows. Let $G$ be a Lie group and $\mathfrak g = T_e G$ . In the first book, Lie bracket is defined using adjoint representation.
For every $g \in G$ conjugation by $g$ , $c_g: G \to G$ is a diffeomorphism that fixes identity. We define adjoint representation $\operatorname{Ad}: G \to \operatorname{Aut} \mathfrak g$ by differentiating $c_g$ at identity, $\operatorname{Ad}(g) = c_{g*}$ . We differentiate once more at identity to obtain $\operatorname{ad}: \mathfrak g \to \operatorname{End}(\mathfrak g)$ , $\operatorname{ad} = \operatorname{Ad}_{*}$ .
Then, Lie bracket on $\mathfrak g$ is defined as $[X, Y] = \operatorname{ad}(X)(Y)$ . In the second book, we first define Lie bracket on smooth vector fields and left-invariant vector fields on $G$ (these are vector fields invariant to differential of left multiplication by $g$ , for every $g$ in $G$ ). Next, we notice that vector space of left-invariant vector fields is Lie bracket-closed and isomorphic to $\mathfrak g$ .
Lie bracket on $\mathfrak g$ is transported from Lie bracket on left-invariant vector fields by that isomorphism.
